jassimp

Class AiLight

  • java.lang.Object
    • jassimp.AiLight

  • public final class AiLight
extends java.lang.Object
    Describes a light source.

    Assimp supports multiple sorts of light sources, including directional, point and spot lights. All of them are defined with just a single structure and distinguished by their parameters. Note - some file formats (such as 3DS, ASE) export a "target point" - the point a spot light is looking at (it can even be animated). Assimp writes the target point as a subnode of a spotlights's main node, called "<spotName>.Target". However, this is just additional information then, the transformation tracks of the main node make the spot light already point in the right direction.

    • Method Detail

      • getName

        public java.lang.String getName()
        Returns the name of the light source.

        There must be a node in the scenegraph with the same name. This node specifies the position of the light in the scene hierarchy and can be animated.

        Returns:
        the name

      • getType

        public AiLightType getType()
        Returns The type of the light source.
        Returns:
        the type

      • getPosition

        public <V3,M4,C,N,Q> V3 getPosition(AiWrapperProvider<V3,M4,C,N,Q> wrapperProvider)
        Returns the position of the light.

        The position is relative to the transformation of the scene graph node corresponding to the light. The position is undefined for directional lights.

        This method is part of the wrapped API (see AiWrapperProvider for details on wrappers).

        The built in behavior is to return an AiVector.

        Parameters:
        wrapperProvider - the wrapper provider (used for type inference)
        Returns:
        the position

      • getDirection

        public <V3,M4,C,N,Q> V3 getDirection(AiWrapperProvider<V3,M4,C,N,Q> wrapperProvider)
        Returns the direction of the light.

        The direction is relative to the transformation of the scene graph node corresponding to the light. The direction is undefined for point lights. The vector may be normalized, but it needn't..

        This method is part of the wrapped API (see AiWrapperProvider for details on wrappers).

        The built in behavior is to return an AiVector.

        Parameters:
        wrapperProvider - the wrapper provider (used for type inference)
        Returns:
        the position

      • getAttenuationConstant

        public float getAttenuationConstant()
        Constant light attenuation factor.

        The intensity of the light source at a given distance 'd' from the light's position is Atten = 1/( att0 + att1 * d + att2 * d*d) This member corresponds to the att0 variable in the equation. Naturally undefined for directional lights.

        Returns:
        the constant light attenuation factor

      • getAttenuationLinear

        public float getAttenuationLinear()
        Linear light attenuation factor.

        The intensity of the light source at a given distance 'd' from the light's position is Atten = 1/( att0 + att1 * d + att2 * d*d) This member corresponds to the att1 variable in the equation. Naturally undefined for directional lights.

        Returns:
        the linear light attenuation factor

      • getAttenuationQuadratic

        public float getAttenuationQuadratic()
        Quadratic light attenuation factor.

        The intensity of the light source at a given distance 'd' from the light's position is Atten = 1/( att0 + att1 * d + att2 * d*d) This member corresponds to the att2 variable in the equation. Naturally undefined for directional lights.

        Returns:
        the quadratic light attenuation factor

      • getColorDiffuse

        public <V3,M4,C,N,Q> C getColorDiffuse(AiWrapperProvider<V3,M4,C,N,Q> wrapperProvider)
        Diffuse color of the light source.

        The diffuse light color is multiplied with the diffuse material color to obtain the final color that contributes to the diffuse shading term.

        This method is part of the wrapped API (see AiWrapperProvider for details on wrappers).

        The built in behavior is to return an AiColor.

        Parameters:
        wrapperProvider - the wrapper provider (used for type inference)
        Returns:
        the diffuse color (alpha will be 1)

      • getColorSpecular

        public <V3,M4,C,N,Q> C getColorSpecular(AiWrapperProvider<V3,M4,C,N,Q> wrapperProvider)
        Specular color of the light source.

        The specular light color is multiplied with the specular material color to obtain the final color that contributes to the specular shading term.

        This method is part of the wrapped API (see AiWrapperProvider for details on wrappers).

        The built in behavior is to return an AiColor.

        Parameters:
        wrapperProvider - the wrapper provider (used for type inference)
        Returns:
        the specular color (alpha will be 1)

      • getColorAmbient

        public <V3,M4,C,N,Q> C getColorAmbient(AiWrapperProvider<V3,M4,C,N,Q> wrapperProvider)
        Ambient color of the light source.

        The ambient light color is multiplied with the ambient material color to obtain the final color that contributes to the ambient shading term. Most renderers will ignore this value it, is just a remaining of the fixed-function pipeline that is still supported by quite many file formats.

        This method is part of the wrapped API (see AiWrapperProvider for details on wrappers).

        The built in behavior is to return an AiColor.

        Parameters:
        wrapperProvider - the wrapper provider (used for type inference)
        Returns:
        the ambient color (alpha will be 1)

      • getAngleInnerCone

        public float getAngleInnerCone()
        Inner angle of a spot light's light cone.

        The spot light has maximum influence on objects inside this angle. The angle is given in radians. It is 2PI for point lights and undefined for directional lights.

        Returns:
        the inner angle

      • getAngleOuterCone

        public float getAngleOuterCone()
        Outer angle of a spot light's light cone.

        The spot light does not affect objects outside this angle. The angle is given in radians. It is 2PI for point lights and undefined for directional lights. The outer angle must be greater than or equal to the inner angle. It is assumed that the application uses a smooth interpolation between the inner and the outer cone of the spot light.

        Returns:
        the outer angle
